As you know, the commercial industry has been under attack from both- the
public and its representative in Congress and the FCC. The latter body,
under Mr. Minow’s leadership,has repeatedly indicated that it has a respon¬
sibility and authority to concern itself with stations’ programs. As earnest
of its intention to do something about programming,it has indicated that it
will be paying increasing attention to discrepancies between program pro¬
mises and performance when it comes to license renewals .
The result of this crackdown on station programming is that the station
manager at long last is convinced that the FCC means what it -gays and is
going to get tough; hence stations are belatedly becoming very worried about
how to beef up the educational content of their schedules. To capitalize
on their concern,NAEB has just issued a flyer calling to their attention the
splendid selection of high quality educational programs available from its
tape library.
The FCC has also indicated that in considering renewals of licenses it will
pay attention to how well a station has geared its programming to meet the
needs and interests of the community it serves. They have also indicated
that in satisfying this requirement a station is not going to be able to just
“fly by the seat of its pants”, be guided by questions the director asks at
the bar of the local Elks club, or use any other quaint divining rods which
have gotten them by in the past. In fact, this means audience surveys.
